head.title: In a Coup, Former Underlings Banish the Bedspread

hedline.hl1: In a Coup, Former Underlings Banish the Bedspread

abstract.p: Personal Shopper column on blankets and bed linens; photo (M)

block.p: DESIGNERS increasingly believe that the blanket makes the bed, even in summer (perhaps especially in summer, if the air-conditioner is blasting all night). Angel Zimick, a clothing designer who also creates bed linens and towels, dresses her beds in layers of blankets made of couture fabrics, believing them to be more decorative than bedspreads. ''Blankets add layers of texture and pattern to the top of the bed,'' she said.

DESIGNERS increasingly believe that the blanket makes the bed, even in summer (perhaps especially in summer, if the air-conditioner is blasting all night). Angel Zimick, a clothing designer who also creates bed linens and towels, dresses her beds in layers of blankets made of couture fabrics, believing them to be more decorative than bedspreads. ''Blankets add layers of texture and pattern to the top of the bed,'' she said.

1. From top: Ms. Zimick's fall collection includes her merino wool Printed Squares, full or queen, $425; also in red, olive green or gray at ABC Carpet & Home, 888 Broadway (19th Street). Confetti, her chocolate-brown felted-wool blanket with small laser-cut squares, costs $485 at Property, 14 Wooster Street (Canal Street). The boldy patterned acrylic blanket is by Boaz Sade, an Israeli knitwear designer; twin size costs $1,000, full/queen is $1,100 and king is $1,200, at Auto, 805 Washington Street (Gansevoort Street). A washed-wool twin blanket, $185, here in green and natural, is also a colorful topper for a larger bed; made in Norway on vintage looms, this pattern, from a collection of 12, also comes in orange, black, yellow, red and lavender versions; from Simplii Scandii at Marketfair in Princeton, N.J., (800) 929-7226.

2. From top: Italian bed linens by Redaelli in bright orange, $233 for a pair of pillowcases and $485 for a bottom sheet, at B&B Italia, 150 East 58th Street. Dana, an acrylic blanket shown in purple with a white reverse, also comes in gray, camel or taupe, all reversing to white; $49.99 to $89.99 at Bed Bath & Beyond, (800) 462-3966. The fine maroon and white herringbone, a blend of cotton and acrylic, also comes in blue, navy or hunter green, all with white; $32.50 for a twin and $49.99 for king from Miller & Jo in Lisbon Falls, Me.; www.mjblankets.com or (207) 353-4371. Rock Art by Pendleton is inspired by American Indian rock carvings; reversible, with beige, red or green background, $200 (queen only) from (877) 796-4663.

3. From top: Equus, in red angora with leather trim; other colors are orange, white, camel, green or brown; $875 for queen; orders from Blakes 988, 988 Lexington Avenue (72nd Street). Meridiani, a lamb's wool blanket by Paola Lenti, here in green, also comes in orange, red, blue, gray or beige, all with white stripes; twin size is $1,170, full/queen $1,370, at Property. The tartan plaid in red and green wool is $99 for twin, $149 for full/queen and $189 for king; from the Pottery Barn Bed & Bath catalog, (888) 779-4044.

4. From top: A vintage cotton plaid Beacon blanket, $245 from a collection of old textiles at Paula Rubenstein, 65 Prince Street (Lafayette Street). Miller & Jo's herringbone in green (see No. 2). The green plaid in washable wool is $85 for twin, $105 for full/queen and $120 for king from the Garnet Hill catalog, (800) 622-6216.
